item.title: Introduce Yourself (Example Post)
item.dc:creator: azcanta
item.content:encoded:
This is an example post, originally published as part of Blogging University. Enroll in one of our ten programs, and start your blog right.

You’re going to publish a post today. Don’t worry about how your blog looks. Don’t worry if you haven’t given it a name yet, or you’re feeling overwhelmed. Just click the “New Post” button, and tell us why you’re here.

Why do this?

  • Because it gives new readers context. What are you about? Why should they read your blog?
  • Because it will help you focus your own ideas about your blog and what you’d like to do with it.

The post can be short or long, a personal intro to your life or a bloggy mission statement, a manifesto for the future or a simple outline of your the types of things you hope to publish.

To help you get started, here are a few questions:

  • Why are you blogging publicly, rather than keeping a personal journal?
  • What topics do you think you’ll write about?
  • Who would you love to connect with via your blog?
  • If you blog successfully throughout the next year, what would you hope to have accomplished?

You’re not locked into any of this; one of the wonderful things about blogs is how they constantly evolve as we learn, grow, and interact with one another — but it’s good to know where and why you started, and articulating your goals may just give you a few other post ideas.

Can’t think how to get started? Just write the first thing that pops into your head. Anne Lamott, author of a book on writing we love, says that you need to give yourself permission to write a “crappy first draft”. Anne makes a great point — just start writing, and worry about editing it later.

When you’re ready to publish, give your post three to five tags that describe your blog’s focus — writing, photography, fiction, parenting, food, cars, movies, sports, whatever. These tags will help others who care about your topics find you in the Reader. Make sure one of the tags is “zerotohero,” so other new bloggers can find you, too.

item.title: About Jingyan
item.dc:creator: azcanta
item.content:encoded:
Hello, I'm Jingyan Wu, I also go by Steven. Welcome to my Blog!

I'm from Shanghai. I'm currently majoring in Communication and Economics. I love sightseeing, coffee brewing, and playing games. I love go for trip with my friends during holidays. We will flying drones for pictures, and tasting various cuisines.

Travelling and Foods

During the Covid season when I'm in my hometown, I frequently travel to other cities in China with my friends. Here are the pictures I went to Xian last year, a city full of history. That's where I discovered this fabulous night views.

I'm not a gourmet but I'd wish to try all delicious food in the world! It's a little bit sad that during Covid season I can't travel for exotic foods.

Coffee Brew Lover!

When stay at home, I like to brew my own coffee. Honestly, it will definitely take more time than buying one in Starbucks or the illy, but I enjoy the time making the pour-over.

The moment when boiled water get touched with the coffee powder, and the nice smell will made my day.

Me making coffee, Photographed by Alex Zhang

Personal Remarks about Blog Posting

Within this blogpost site, I would like to focus more on creating contents, especially the design. When I was doing my web publishing class (ITP 104), I first get exposed to design webpages and manage them. But that course focus more on the coding and I feel like I could do something different this time.

Here is my previous work in ITP 104:

  • Interest Page | Arknights
  • Monster Hunter World Project
Sources I Trusted and Consumed

We lived in an age of information, we consume information every day. Just like what I shared in my first blog post, we spend of lot of time looking at media content, and news is a part of it.

I personally love reading news about global economies and politics, so my news channel pick could be less diverged, as follow:

  • Wall Street Journal, a business-focused newspaper, have a lot of reports about government policy
  • Bloomberg, one of the most famous finance and business news provider
  • Jinri TouTiao (Today's Headline), powered by ByteDance (parent company of Tiktok), is a Chinese news sources. I use it to keep track of things happen in my home country.
  • Yahoo Finance, another news sources on financial market
  • Facebook various news official channel, just get a "carousel" view of all different news
What I'm following now

I usually consume serious news on official websites, so most of the people and organizations I'm following are for fun! (P.S. most of them are foods and coffee)

  • VVCafe on YouTube, a channel for coffee brewing lovers!
  • Chef Wang on YouTube, a channel for how to cooking authentic Chinese Cuisine
  • Who's'HU on YouTube, an Austrian sharing European foods and cultures
  • Kimagure Cook on YouTube, all about seafoods in Japanese cooking style!
  • Poseidon with a bow on YouTube, First Violin section at LA Opera, a music lover

item.title: Is "Media" Means or the End?
item.dc:creator: azcanta
item.content:encoded:
Until I finish my media consumption log, I just can’t believe how my life is surrounded by media of many kinds. I mean think about it, when you get up in the morning, the first thing you go for is media content (personally, that’s the social media time). And the last thing before you lay down on your bed is consuming somewhat of media content. Not joking. That’s what my typical life looks like.

Therefore, I think “timeline” is not a perfect form anymore to track my media consumption. Instead, I will use “timecircle,” a made-up word by myself. Let me show you how my “timecirle” looks like:

Here the media content can be anything. Mine will be primarily social media, games, and YouTube videos. For simplification, I didn’t put everything I do (aka multitasking stuff) into these time slots. Even though I can allocate everything from the timeline to this circle, the pervasive nature of my media life isn’t changing. I consume media content A LOT.

Here the question comes: why am I using any sort of media throughout the day? The answer, from my experience, can be either:

  • I use media purposefully because it’s convenient, vivid, etc. (use media as means)
  • Media is a part of my life. I can’t imagine a life without it. (treat media as ends)

These two answers treat media consumption differently in essence, which implies that using media can be either the path to achieving something else or achieving themselves. Let’s move on to these two scenarios.

Use Media as the mean

The digital age has shifted our use preference a lot, which turns out to be one of the most potent explanations why we love them so much.

Think about how tech companies are constantly making better and better User Interfaces (UI) and Recommendation algorithms. I recall that when I start learning to brew coffee myself, I click into one of the basic tutorials, and afterward, 5 more similar videos are waiting for me. More astonishingly, when I came back to YouTube later, some brewers’ channel just pop-up on the home page. That’s the power of personal recommendation.

Curious about yours? Feel free to jump out of from this blog to your own YouTube and see whether you've get personalized recommendation.

You can say that the experience is a bit bizarre because the AI predicts what you want. It’s true that right now, those media try so hard to understand us and provided personalized experience adaptation to the platform. I will say everyone’s media platform is UNIQUE, which is designed for you. And that possibly answer why we are so into media consumption; they are created by you (with the using history) and are helping them with your need.

Use Media as the end

Using media as the end is more likely the opposite since we will be consuming media for no reason. I don’t think we are not approaching this condition yet. But what about checking social media right after getting up? Is that time being permanently occupied by social media? Good, good question. I can definitely say that I want to keep in touch with friends, but can I wait 5 minutes for that? Probably no.

To wrap up the thoughts, media consumption is infused into everyone’s life and cannot simply be eliminated. When we start considering why media consumption happens and, further on, the relationship between us and media, there are infinite-many intriguing topics to discuss.

item.title: What Went Wrong with the Pandemic News
item.dc:creator: azcanta
item.content:encoded:
Outdoor dining near a mobile vaccine clinic providing coronavirus vaccinations in West Palm Beach, Florida. Pictures: New York Times

Beginning with a title of "What Went Wrong With the Pandemic in Florida," an article from the New York Times alarmed the rising Covid-19 cases in Florida— both infection and death rate soar high. The authors aim to persuade the audience by analyzing the rigorous situation that state government and citizens in Florida were facing. Florida is indeed facing trouble dealing with spiraling Covid cases, but any opinions further from pure facts need careful examination, let me walk you through.

"All the news that's fit to print"?

The quote came from Adolph S. Ochs, the founder of the New York Times. His remarks highlight that New York Times was born to report news impartially. The spirit is also inherited in the company's latest handbook of Ethical Journalism, which underlines the essentiality of treating readers and news sources fairly and avoiding conflicting interests.

Note that there's nothing wrong with being persuasive if there is no monetary or political interest involved. According to TREFIS, around 60% of the company's revenue comes from readers' subscription, and another 31% come from advertising. The audience is loosely correlated with a single article, and there is no advertisement in the news. Therefore, the New York Times has no further motivation other than persuading that Florida failed to do a great job fighting against Covid.

The author's motivation could be more debatable. Patricia Mazzei used to be a political writer for the Miami Herald, which may hold some interest in politics. As Governor Ron DeSantis was being blamed for banning strict mask mandate in public schools in the state, it could be the reason why this news article is trying to sway from the ban, portraying DeSantis as a responsible governor. For readers live in Florida but not familiar with the ban, this article serve as a political propaganda favoring DeSantis. The two other authors are primarily scientific-focused, who are specialized in Covid news and data processing. Since the exact portion of contribution from these three authors is unknown, I would suggest being a little bit dubious on any content related to politics, especially the comment on Governor DeSantis.

The sources are astonishingly sparse, and few stand high in PIE criteria

Surprisingly, the only source that shows high in all three elements of the PIE chart is the CDC data about the mortality rates in Florida! To examine, that data from is high in proximity since it visualizes the growing mortality rate trend in two age groups, foreshadowing a severe situation the state is facing. It's independence because it's not an affiliation of state government or the New York Times. It's high in expertise because the calculation seriously follows the FDA conduct.

The author quoted Natalie E. Dean's words on the disturbance of academic research fail to pass the PIE credibility matrix. In this source, Natalie merely shared a personal experience of how life is disturbed by the Covid outbreak. I would argue that the expertise in Natalie's case is low even she is a biostatistician since the content is not even related to her specialty. A source that is low in either determinant of PIE ruins the credibility.

A rhetorical device used in evidence

However, the incredible source from Natalie constructs very persuasive evidence. I'm not suggesting that's valid evidence but a really effective one. The use of ethos, or appeal to emotion is used, making the article convincing even without data. The appeal to emotion aims to echo the sympathy from readers, imparting the experience from the storyteller to the reader. Nevertheless, it creates an illusion in front of the reader, witnessing someone's life being destroyed by Covid. Valid evidence can be what people witness but should never be an illusion in an article.

The logic is easy to follow

The logical flow of this news article is consistent and straightforward. The news addresses a deep analysis of the state's vaccination rate and constructs a demographic evaluation further. When discerning the vaccination rate among elderly people, the author clearly identified the nursing house as where most elderly people live and addressed substantial evidence to show that the vaccination rate is relatively low compared to other states, which has the way to improve. There is also evidence from the epidemiologist's quote on the vulnerability of aged people toward covid, firmly compelling the reasoning.

Vaccination is not a panacea!

One of the omissions in the article that entail bias is that the authors fail to discuss to function of masks. Many states, including California, had imposed mask mandates because its effectiveness in preventing virus spread. Clearly, the author wants to present a value that vaccination is a panacea, which is misleading. The role of masks is marginalized probably because the author won't convince the audience that Governor's ban on strict mask mandate on public school is ridiculous.

You may argue that what if the author forgets? Probably. But how much should you believe in someone who fails to mention the importance of wearing a mask in a Covid topic?

item.title: "We lose SpaceRace, Comrade General."
item.dc:creator: azcanta
item.content:encoded:
In July 20, 1969, 20:17:40 UTC, the Apollo 11 landed on the moon. Astronaut Neil Armstrong commented on this mission as "One small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind."

The Iconic image of Apollo 11, also the image I'm going to edit.

The image itself is precious not only because it was took on the moon, but also it shown U.S. was leading the aerospace technology.

We can see astronaut salute besides the nation flag. that was definitely a cheerful moment in history.

Manipulating image in historical angle

Indeed it's a rewarding moment for all Americans. But it wouldn't be a happy time for Soviet Union. The whole Apollo 11 mission was carried out during the Cold War. The competition between U.S. and Soviet Union at that time is a life-or-death game. Let's see how Soviet Union and its media would felt about the mission:

The message in this photoshopped image is: The Soviet Union newspaper reported their president Nikita Khrushchev mad about losing space race on moon landing.

Story behind the message

With the Soviet Union angle in mind, I manipulated the iconic Apollo image to make it appear on the Pravda, one of the most widely-read newspaper during that time. I believe that the Apollo mission is so important news that it would definitely appear on the front page.

I also get to decide whether to photoshopping a soviet propaganda which contempt for the mission, saying it's fake. I personally believe the mission is true and I think the Soviet party would know it better than me since two countries were so close in the race. I felt the Soviet Party would accept that but angry about they couldn't be the first. That's also why I wrote the title of the news as "Send Our Spaceship tomorrow."

Used-Elements

To help present the alternative meaning better, I used several elements, as listed:

  • Pravda Newspaper: It help shape the whole image in Soviet Union scenario.
  • Khrushchev portrait: One of the image is he being mad; I attracted emblem from second image.
  • Rocket Launch: This help enhance the whole focus on space race in newspaper.
  • Soviet Union Symbol: I placed it on the emblem on Khrushchev's cloth, try to clarify him being Soviet president.
  • English Title: Help settle the core message of manipulated image.

item.title: U.S. Default—Next Bankruptcy In Line?
item.dc:creator: azcanta
item.content:encoded:
In the early October, the story of US may default on its debt triggered the debate on government debt. As an economics student who learnt about high credibility of US government, the news gave me a real shock. I believed the potential credit default is a social issues, which demand public attentions. Check out what's going on!

Topic Choice

It is natural to choose "declining trust in institution" as the topic. Government debt are issued by the treasury department, an affiliation to the U.S. government. The key issue is government doesn’t have enough money to pay back what they have borrowed. Therefore the default crisis that current government facing rings a bell of its declining trust.

What is debt ceiling? What does credit default mean?

Since I'm addressing an issue that is kind of academic, I need to explain some economics terms before moving on to the cause and effect. In the first part of remix, I was looking for some informative footage that explain concepts both vocally and visually.

I come across with this visual representation of government spending = tax + debt.

Another interesting footage I found is this animation of national debt hitting the debt ceiling. The debt ceiling is a limit, so I believe the red line here explain the concept in a relative easy way.

What might happen next?

The next section of my remix is a list of potential results if US truly default. This part will ideally demonstrate the catastrophic effect on all American people, which makes the issue an urgent one.

The premiere tutorial gave me the idea of cutting three 'catastrophic' together. It's an interesting way to show the intensity of this social issue.

I also make use of the 'montage' technique in the following two clips. Here I want to show that the credit default is causing a wide-spreading negative effect. I take advantage of the ripple caused by a waterdrop to represent the spreading trend. And then I switch to a dramatic market drop in the candlestick graph.

Economics decision on Politician's hand?!

Since this social issue is a economic problem, my instinct is to find what economists and investment bankers advocate. But all of them suggested that raising the debt ceiling is the only way.

However, the senator republicans block the bill of raising the debt ceiling, make the economic issue a political games. We have to question how credible the government is when there is full of pure politics.

I hope my video can expose current 'unhealthy' political environment in the government entity, and call for politicians' attention to focus more on the economic threats all Americans are facing right now.

Music Choice

After I gathered up all footages above, I realized that I need some music to boost the mood of my video. Especially when I go over all the official speech and news footages I've covered, I found out most of them are neutral in emotions.

Therefore I chose the music: [Arknights] 明日方舟 OST1 ｜ 旅途前方. Available on Spotify

  • The music begin with a solo piano solo mixing with some repeating electronic sound. The slow rhythm facilitate the storytelling, when I’m explaining what debt ceiling is. I also noticed clock tickling in the rhythm, just like a warning before crisis!
  • Then it comes with violin, the pace of the rhythm just fitting perfectly when I addressing the cause of debt default, potential solution, and two-parities tension.

From this project I’m impressed that an appropriate, good music can actually "amplify" the message . That explain why films and video games spend a lot of money on music.

Used Sources
  • Janet Yellen, Jerome Powell outline the cost of a U.S. debt default, Sep 30, 2021
  • Why The U.S. Can’t Go Broke, Apr 14, 2021
  • How U.S. debt default could impact Americans and the global economy, Sep 30, 2021
  • U.S. debt default could happen by October 18, Sep 28, 2021
  • What to know about the possible economic fallout over the debt limit, Sep 23, 2021
  • Senate Republicans block bill to avert government shutdown and debt default, Sep 28, 2021
  • Senate debates raising U.S. debt ceiling to prevent country going into default, Sep 22, 2021
  • What is the U.S. debt ceiling and what are the consequences of breaching it?, Jul 31, 2021
  • President Trump Claims Universal Mail-In Voting Will Be ‘Catastrophic’, Aug 16, 2020
  • "Previously on ...", Apr 5, 2010
  • How to Pronounce Capitol Hill | Capitol Hill Pronunciation, Oct 1, 2020.
  • Understanding the debt ceiling and why Congress needs to act soon, Oct 5, 2021
  • Republicans block bill to fund the government, shutdown looms, Sep 27, 2021
  • Biden Says 'I Have No Idea If There Will Be a Republican Party' in 2024, Mar 25, 2021
  • Why the US is always hitting a "debt ceiling", Oct 20, 2021
  • The Debt Ceiling, Explained, Oct 15, 2013
  • The Debt Ceiling Explained: Why You Should Care, Feb 4, 2013
  • Debt Ceiling Standoff 2021: What It Means for Investors, Sep 29, 2021
  • What Would Happen If the U.S. Defaults for the First Time in History?, Oct 6, 2021
  • WHAT HAPPENS IF THE U.S. DEFAULTS ON ITS DEBT? | DEBT CEILING CRISES EXPLAINED, Sep 29, 2021
  • Water Drop Footage Full HD #1 Free Royalty, Jan 24, 2019
  • Fed Chair Jerome Powell holds press briefing on FOMC meeting and interest rates, Jul 28, 2021
  • What is Inflation?, Aug 3, 2015
  • What is the debt ceiling and why is Congress arguing over it again?, Sep 23, 2021
  • Congress at odds over how to avoid default on nation’s debt, Sep 27, 2021
